instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hi, I have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. When I first started working on it it would draw .025A and then go up to .115A or so. I found that I am missing <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>. I traced it back to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> so I removed it and replaced with a donor <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. Board fires up, draws about 800mA and has a three beep pattern. Not sure of where to go from here

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
3 beeps means RAM, or CPU issue.
As you found a problem on the power rail of both, possibly overvoltage could damage the CPU-RAM data bus.

You can try to reflow RAM chips and maybe CPU; pray a lot too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>

threads.message: Yeah I think that is what happened. i threw it in the donor pile
